Job Title: Assistant Scientist

The University of Miami is considered among the top tier institutions of higher education in the U.S. for its academic excellence, superior medical care, and cutting-edge research. At the U, we are committed to attracting a talented workforce to support our common purpose of transforming lives through teaching, research, and service. Through our values of Diversity, Integrity, Responsibility, Excellence, Compassion, Creativity and Teamwork (DIRECCT) we strive to create an environment where everyone contributes in making UM a great place to work. We are one of the largest private employers in Miami-Dade County; home to more than 13,400 faculty and staff from all over the world.

Assistant Scientist This position will work directly with the Principal Investigator, Dr. Abigail Hackam, to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms of optic nerve regeneration. Duties may include, but are not limited to, conducting independent experiments that will contribute to the research project; confocal microscopy; preparing samples for mass spectrometry; assisting with mouse surgeries; intraocular drug delivery; in vivo measurement of retina function using PERG analysis, OCT imaging, data analysis and troubleshooting; tissue processing and immunohistochemistry, protein and nucleic acid analyses, cell culture, cell signaling assays; solving experimental problems that may arise in pursuing the project objectives, including adaptation of techniques from the literature or developing novel techniques; maintaining accurate laboratory records; maintaining current knowledge of literature in the area of the research project; writing manuscripts describing the research performed and assisting in the writing of grant proposals to bring funding to the lab for multiple research projects; presenting data at laboratory meetings and at national and international meetings; and training and supervising undergraduate and graduate students in the lab.The minimum qualifications for this position are as follows: Ph.D. with previous experience with laboratory techniques, including evidence of research productivity such as publications or meeting presentations. Excellent communication skills, both verbal and written, with command of the English language. Must be logically-driven, detail oriented, have high integrity, well organized and have the potential to continue learning. Must have the ability to work independently. Ability to demonstrate a strong background in molecular, cellular or developmental neuroscience, preferably with experience with transgenic animals.

The minimum qualifications for this position are as follows: Ph.D. or M.D. or other doctoral level degree and one (1) year of relevant post-doctoral experience. Previous experience with laboratory techniques, including evidence of research productivity such as publications or meeting presentations. Excellent communication skills, both verbal and written, with command of the English language. Must be logically-driven, detail oriented, have high integrity, well organized and have the potential to continue learning. Must have the ability to work independently. Ability to demonstrate a strong background in molecular, cellular or developmental neuroscience, preferably with experience with transgenic animals.
